1.1:
Welcome to the Touch Typing Course!

Touch typing is a technique for typing quicker and more accurately by using all ten fingers without looking at the keys.

The core idea is to learn the location of keys by muscle memory.

This means your fingers will know where to go without your eyes guiding them. This saves time and reduces neck strain.

To begin, place your fingers on the 'Home Row' (A S D F and J K L ;).

Your index fingers should rest on F and J, which usually have small bumps to help you find them by touch.
1.1.2:
Place your fingers on the HOME ROW.

LEFT HAND:
Little finger on A
Ring finger on S
Middle finger on D
Index finger on F

RIGHT HAND:
Index finger on J
Middle finger on K
Ring finger on L
Little finger on ;

sad all add as dad as
salad salsa dad fall falls
flask asks all dad sad
add a dad ask a lad
fall as a lad asks
sad dad all fall
lass asks dad all as

2.2.1:
Reach for the top row.

Key E: Use your LEFT MIDDLE finger. Reach up from D.
Key I: Use your RIGHT MIDDLE finger. Reach up from K.

Keep your other fingers on the home row while reaching.
2.2:
How long should you practice?

For best results, practice in short bursts of 15-30 minutes daily.
Consistency is more important than duration. Practicing for 2 hours once a week is less effective than 20 minutes every day.
Your brain needs sleep to consolidate muscle memory. So, daily practice with good rest is the secret formula for speed.

2.5:
What is the Typing Meter?

The Typing Meter is a widget that tracks your typing in real-world applications.

It analyzes your typing while you write emails, reports, or chat.

It then identifies your 'Problem Keys' and suggests custom training lessons to fix them.

3.3.1:
Use your INDEX fingers for R and U.

Key R: Reach up and left with your LEFT INDEX finger from F.
Key U: Reach up and left with your RIGHT INDEX finger from J.

surf sure user safe
dual duel duke dusk
3.3:
Ergonomics is key to preventing injury.

1. Sit straight with your back supported.
2. Keep your feet flat on the floor.

3. Your screen should be at eye level so you don't bend your neck.
4. Your elbows should be at a 90-degree angle.
Most importantly: float your wrists above the keyboard. Do not rest them on the desk while typing, as this compresses the nerves.
3.6:
Learning should be fun!

Typing games are a great way to improve your speed and reaction time without feeling like 'work'.
Try out the 'Bubbles' game to practice letter recognition, or 'WordTris' to practice typing common words under time pressure.

4.4.1:
Extend your index and ring fingers for T and O.

Key T: Reach up and right with your LEFT INDEX finger from F.
Key O: Reach up and left with your RIGHT RING finger from L.

4.4:
Track your progress!

After each lesson, check the Statistics Dashboard. It gives you a detailed breakdown of your Net Speed (WPM) and Accuracy.

Look for the 'Difficulty Index'. This tells you exactly which keys you are struggling with.

If you see a red key, it means you need more practice on that specific letter.

5.5.1:
Use the Shift key to type capital letters.

Use the PINKY finger on the OPPOSITE hand of the letter you are typing.
Example: To type 'A', hold RIGHT SHIFT with right pinky, strike 'A' with left pinky.

5.5.3:
Key Period (.): Use your RIGHT RING finger. Reach down from L.

Remember to tap lightly and return to the home row immediately.

5.5:
Rhythm is the secret to speed.

Try to type with an even rhythm, like a steady drumbeat or a metronome.

It is better to slow down and type steadily than to sprint through easy words and get stuck on hard ones.

A steady pace reduces errors, and fewer errors ultimately means faster typing.
Don't worry about speed for now. Focus on the rhythm.

6.6.1:
Reach down to the bottom row.

Key C: Use your LEFT MIDDLE finger. Reach down from D.
Key Comma (,): Use your RIGHT MIDDLE finger. Reach down from K.

6.5:
Check your posture again!

It makes a big difference. As you get tired, it's easy to slouch.

1. Keep back straight.
2. Relax shoulders.
3. Elbows at 90 degrees.
If you feel tension in your shoulders, take a deep breath and let them drop. Relaxed muscles move faster.

7.7.1:
Learning the center keys.

Key G: Reach right with your LEFT INDEX finger from F.
Key H: Reach left with your RIGHT INDEX finger from J.
7.7.2: Key Apostrophe ('): Use your RIGHT PINKY. Reach right from Semicolon (;).

7.5:
Don't forget to take breaks!

Typing for long periods can cause Repetitive Strain Injury (RSI).
We recommend the 20-20-20 rule: Every 20 minutes, look at something 20 feet away for 20 seconds.
Also, stand up and stretch every hour to keep good blood flow.

12.5:
Testing your skills.

Regular typing tests help measure your progress. However, don't just focus on speed.
Accuracy is the foundation of speed. If you type fast but make many errors, you will spend more time correcting them than typing.
Aim for 98% accuracy or higher. Speed will naturally follow.

12.7: Congratulations! You have completed the basic course.

You have learned all the alphabet keys and basic punctuation.

So, what is next?

1. Continue practicing to build speed.
2. Learn the number row.
3. Master the special symbols.
4. Try the advanced speed building courses.
